But there are major problems with IPEF. First, the Administration has been working on the IPEF for months now, but today‚Äôs announcement said that members would start ‚Äúdiscussions toward future negotiations.‚Äù In other words, at this point we are just talking about talking.

Also, that #Taiwan wasn‚Äôt invited is unconscionable. Taiwan is a high-standards economy & one of our top trading partners. Its inclusion in what amounts to an economic club would have greatly benefited each of the IPEF‚Äôs pillars. Leaving Taiwan out is a needless bow to the #CCP.

The biggest problem with the IPEF is that the Administration failed to include market access provisions, which is what the region really wants, and which would have given us something to offer in exchange for advancing the interests of American workers and businesses.

The Indo-Pacific has 60% of global population and will be the top driver of the world‚Äôs economic growth for decades to come. It‚Äôs absolutely critical that the United States shows economic leadership in a region on which our economic future will increasingly depend.

Therefore, it‚Äôs good to see that in addition to the United States, the IPEF will include Australia, Brunei, India, Indonesia, Japan, Republic of Korea, Malaysia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam, which collectively make up 40% of global GDP.

China is setting the trade rules in the Indo-Pacific to the detriment of American consumers and businesses. The President‚Äôs announcement today of the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework is a welcome step to get us back in the game, but the framework leaves much to be desired.

Yesterday afternoon, I spoke on the House floor in support of my bill to reopen the Paycheck Protection Program. From mom and pop shops to local manufacturers and everything in between, our nation‚Äôs small businesses strengthen our communities and our economy.

Sadly, too many of them are still hurting. PPP loans have supported over 50 million jobs so far‚Äîthat‚Äôs 50 million people in Cincinnati and across America who were able to pay their bills and support their families.

Further delay by Congress jeopardizes small businesses and their employees, who cannot wait until the political logjam has cleared. I urge my colleagues, on both sides of the aisle and in both chambers, to come together and pass a common sense relief package.

The Paycheck Protection Program has bipartisan backing, and supported millions of #SmallBiz jobs.

There is over $130 billion in remaining PPP funds. 

I have introduced legislation that would reopen the program and ensure aid reaches the small businesses that need it most.
My bill, HR 8265, would reopen the Paycheck Protection Program and send relief to mom and pop shops.
I‚Äôve visited over 70 small businesses in my district, many of whom received help through PPP loans. Unfortunately, many small businesses across our nation and our community are still struggling.
